title: 110_s2814
content: The Act is titled the "Eastern New Mexico Rural Water System Authorization Act" and includes definitions for various terms. The Act titled the "Eastern New Mexico Rural Water System Authorization Act" defines key terms such as Authority, Engineering report, Plan, Secretary, State, and System related to the Eastern New Mexico Rural Water System. The Eastern New Mexico Rural Water System is a project to deliver water from the Ute Reservoir to various cities and counties in New Mexico. The Ute Reservoir is an impoundment created by the Ute Dam on the Canadian River. The System includes major components identified in the engineering report as the "Best Technical Alternative." The Eastern New Mexico Rural Water System aims to deliver water from the Ute Reservoir to cities and counties in New Mexico. The Secretary may provide financial and technical assistance to the Authority for planning, designing, and constructing the Eastern New Mexico Rural Water System. Financial assistance must be used in accordance with a cooperative agreement and cannot be used for activities inconsistent with the System or for irrigation water supply facilities. The Federal share of the total cost of the Eastern New Mexico Rural Water System shall not exceed 75 percent. No funds can be used for construction until a plan is developed and environmental requirements are met. Title to the infrastructure of the System will be held by the Authority or as specified under State law. The Authority is responsible for the operation, maintenance, and replacement costs of the System, ensuring it can deliver 16,500 acre-feet of water per year. They will develop a plan with rates and fees in consultation with the Secretary. Administrative provisions are also outlined. The Secretary may enter into agreements necessary to carry out the Act, including a cooperative agreement with the Authority for financial and other assistance in planning, design, and construction of the System. The responsibilities of both parties regarding cost-sharing must be specified in the agreement. The Secretary may provide technical assistance to the Authority for planning, designing, constructing, and operating the System. The Secretary shall consult with relevant entities for preparing any required biological assessment under the Endangered Species Act of 1973. The Act does not affect State water law or interstate compacts related to water allocation, nor does it grant non-Federal entities Federal rights to water resources. SEC. 6. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. An amount not greater than $327,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated to the Secretary for carrying out this Act. The amount will be adjusted to reflect changes in construction costs, and any unexpended funds at the end of each fiscal year will be retained for future use. Amounts received under the cost-sharing requirement will not be reimbursed or returned to the United States.
